title: How to Study Effectively (Without Studying More Hours)

slides.title: How to Study Effectively
slides.subtitle: Without studying more hours
body: Big idea: Study smarter — make practice retrieval and spacing do the heavy lifting.
System > motivation: a repeatable approach beats last-minute willpower.

slides.title: The Problem
body: Most people "study" but don't learn.
Re-reading notes feels productive, but doesn't stick.
Highlighting makes you familiar, not fluent.
Real learning happens when your brain has to retrieve and apply.
slides.note: If studying feels easy, it's probably not working.

slides.title: Insight — Why Now
body: Cognitive science shows retrieval + spacing create durable memory.
Students are time-pressured: swapping technique yields large returns without more hours.

slides.title: Solution — The 3 Rules
body: Active recall: force your brain to pull information out.
Spaced repetition: revisit over time, not in one big block.
Deliberate practice: target what you get wrong, not what you already know.
slides.note: These three are the difference between 'I saw it' and 'I can do it.'

slides.title: How it Works — Core Methods
body: Active recall: Blurting, practice questions, teach-back — do it before reviewing notes.
Spacing & interleaving: short sessions across days + mix topics; it will feel harder, and that's good.
Feedback loop: after every session ask: What did I get wrong? Why? Then prioritize fixes (70% weak, 30% review).

slides.title: Differentiation
body: Re-reading/highlighting = passive familiarity. Retrieval = fluent, applicable knowledge.
This approach builds exam-ready skills because it trains recall under demand, not recognition.
It scales: same system works for vocabulary, problem sets, and conceptual subjects.

slides.title: Use Cases — A Practical Template
body: Simple 45-minute study template:
• 0–5 min: set a specific outcome
• 5–25 min: active recall / questions
• 25–35 min: mark + error log
• 35–45 min: re-attempt wrong questions + schedule next review
No fancy motivation needed—just a system.

slides.title: GTM / Distribution — How to Spread the Practice
body: Embed the template in course syllabi and study-group routines.
Share short retrieval guides and 45-min templates through tutors, apps, and class channels.
Small bets: run a week-long
pilot with a class or cohort.

slides.title: Closing — Try This One Change
body: Effective studying isn't about time. It's about technique.
If you do only one change: swap re-reading for retrieval (practice questions + recall), then space it out.
Try the 45-minute template this week and observe the difference.
